author: ryanleeschneider
content:
That sounds like baseFeePErGas was actually null/nil, not `0`.  A byte w/ value `0x00` should be encoded as `0x80` in RLP, I _think_ in this case a "null byte pointer" would get encoded as the empty list `0xc0`.

edit: or at least this sounds related to the fact that Geth's ExecutableDataV1.BaseFeePerGas data type is `*big.Int`  rather than `big.Int`.

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
Oh wait, I see, it sounds like teku passed in `baseFeePerGas: 0x` in the passed-in JSON when it probably should have passed in `0x0`.  

> that fun case where RLP strips all leading zeros

For the JSONRPC encoding of `QUANTITY` only the _first_ leading zero (if it exists) should be stripped.  So `0x00 -> 0x0`, `0x01 -> 0x1` etc.  I'm unclear where the canonical encoding description for JSONRPC types is these days, but I think it's here: https://eth.wiki/json-rpc/API (under `HEX value encoding`).

edit: ok, I guess `0x0001` still becomes `0x1` so a more correct description of the rule is "after removing any leading 0-value bytes remove the first leading zero if it exists of the hexadecimal representation".
